channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: WikiLeaks Releases Trove of Alleged C.I.A. Hacking Documents
item.media:description: The C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va. If the WikiLeaks documents are authentic, the release would be a serious blow to the agency.
item.description: The documents describe agency tools used to hack into smartphones and TVs, as well as to bypass encryption on programs like Signal and WhatsApp.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE, MATTHEW ROSENBERG and ANDREW W. LEHREN

item.title: With WikiLeaks Claims of C.I.A. Hacking, How Vulnerable Is Your Smartphone?
item.media:description: An iPhone streamed a Facebook Live feed of the lobby at Trump Tower in November.
item.description: Documents released by WikiLeaks indicate the extent to which the spy agency was looking for ways to break into ordinary consumer devices.
item.dc:creator: STEVE LOHR and KATIE BENNER

item.title: Travis Kalanick, Uber’s Chief, Wants a No. 2 Executive
item.media:description: Travis Kalanick, the chief executive of Uber, at a conference in Amsterdam last May.
item.description: After several recent incidents that called into question Uber’s culture and tactics, its chief is looking for help leading the ride-sharing company.
item.dc:creator: KATIE BENNER

item.title: U.S. Fines ZTE of China $1.19 Billion for Breaching Sanctions
item.media:description: Visitors used ZTE devices during the Mobile World Congress 2017 on Feb. 27 in Barcelona. The company’s settlement with the United States is the latest in a series of skirmishes between the United States and China over technology policy.
item.description: The Chinese technology company agreed to plead guilty to charges that it broke United States sanctions and sold electronics to Iran and North Korea.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR and CECILIA KANG

item.title: State of the Art: Snap Makes a Bet on the Cultural Supremacy of the Camera
item.media:description: The rising dependence on cameras is changing the way we communicate.
item.description: Our rising dependence on cameras is changing our language, and the company behind Snapchat is counting on the eventual dominance of visual culture.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: WikiLeaks Reignites Tensions Between Silicon Valley and Spy Agencies
item.media:description: A pedestrian walked by the Apple Store on Fifth Avenue in February 2016 in Manhattan, while a group of demonstrators protested F.B.I. efforts to force Apple to help access the iPhone of an attacker in the 2015 shooting in San Bernardino, Calif.
item.description: Leaked documents appear to indicate that the C.I.A. was collecting cyberweapons that can break into smartphones and even internet-connected televisions.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL and NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos’s Moon Shot, Gets First Paying Customer
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos, founder of the rocket company Blue Origin, spoke about plans for the business at Access Intelligence’s Satellite 2017 conference on Tuesday in Washington.
item.description: In about five years, Eutelsat, a satellite TV provider, will strap one of its satellites to a new Blue Origin rocket to be delivered to space.
item.dc:creator: CECILIA KANG

item.title: Tech Tip: How to Get Windows 10 to Run Older Programs
item.description: Microsoft’s current operating system comes with compatibility settings that may convince outdated applications to work on Windows 10.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Selfie With Merkel by Refugee Became a Legal Case, but Facebook Won in German Court
item.media:description: Anas Modamani, a Syrian refugee, posed for a selfie with Chancellor Angela Merkel in 2015 in Berlin.
item.description: The picture of Anas Modamani with the German chancellor was used in fake news posts about terrorism, and he wanted the social media giant to prevent its use.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: China’s Plan to Build Its Own High-Tech Industries Worries Western Businesses
item.media:description: A Great Wall Motors factory in Baoding, China. The country’s leaders worry that an increasingly well-educated younger generation is rejecting factory work for higher-paid office jobs.
item.description: European and American companies say that a $300 billion effort to make China self-sufficient in important sectors could lead to unfair competition.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Automation Nation: How to Beat the Robots
item.media:description: Kiva robots move racks of merchandise at an Amazon fulfillment center in Tracy, Calif., where there are two robots for every human worker. Policy makers can help prepare people for a time when more jobs are automated.
item.description: Technology leads to growth, but the benefits won’t be automatic, so here are some policies that economists and policy experts think could help workers.
item.dc:creator: CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

item.title: Bits: Tech Roundup: Uber, Lyft and Gridlock in New York
item.description: Subway ridership in New York is down for the first time since 2009. That has coincided with the explosive growth of companies like Uber.
item.dc:creator: JIM KERSTETTER

item.title: The Downside of Ride-Hailing: More New York City Gridlock
item.media:description: A Lyft ride on the Upper East Side.
item.media:credit: Edu Bayer for The New York Times
item.description: Ride-hailing apps, an existential threat to taxis, are also siphoning passengers from subways and buses, raising concerns over worsening congestion.
item.dc:creator: EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS and WINNIE HU

item.title: Activists Rush to Save Government Science Data — If They Can Find It
item.media:description: “Data rescuers” at New York University last month.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: The Trump administration has begun changing some government websites. A group of concerned citizens has been working to preserve data it sees as politically vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: AMY HARMON

item.title: An Artist Helps iTunes’ User Agreement Go Down Easy
item.media:description: Steve Jobs (or someone like him), meet Homer Simpson (or someone like him).
item.description: A new Drawn and Quarterly graphic novel by the artist Robert Sikoryak adapts Apple’s legalese into a work invoking more than a century of comics.
item.dc:creator: JOE COSCARELLI

item.title: A Conversation With: Why We Can’t Look Away From Our Screens
item.media:description: Adam Alter warns that many of us — youngsters, teenagers, adults — are addicted to modern digital products.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: In a new book, the social psychologist Adam Alter warns that our devotion to digital devices has morphed into something very much like addiction.
item.dc:creator: CLAUDIA DREIFUS

item.title: Bits: Tech Roundup: America’s Cyberwar Against North Korea
item.media:description: The KN-14, one of two types of intercontinental ballistic missiles that North Korea is developing, at a military parade in the capital, Pyongyang, in October 2015, in an image released by the nation's government.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.description: President Trump’s accusatory tweets against his predecessor drew attention from news of an effort to thwart North Korea’s nuclear missile program.
item.dc:creator: JIM KERSTETTER

item.title: Tech Tip: Questions About Mac Security and Google Password Prompts
item.description: You can link your mail accounts and social media services to Apple’s operating system for easy integration, but keep your passwords up to date.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Yelp Starts Tracking Gender-Neutral Bathrooms for Transgender Users
item.media:description: A gender-neutral public restroom sign in West Hollywood, Calif. Yelp will soon offer an option to let users filter searches for establishments with gender-neutral bathrooms.
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.description: The company may ultimately be able to assemble the largest directory of transgender-friendly bathrooms, but it is not the first to try.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: Turkey to Investigate Antitrust Complaint Against Google
item.media:description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, center with flowers, and his wife Emine Erdogan, also holding flowers, at a rally with supporters in Istanbul. Turkey is investigating whether Google has violated its antitrust laws. Mr. Erdogan has repeatedly blocked Google, YouTube and other websites because he feared they were fomenting dissent.
item.description: The country’s competition authority will look at whether the search giant unfairly promotes its own digital services on Android over those of rivals.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Welcome, Airbnb Guest! Your Neighbors Are the Trumps
item.media:description: Police officers outside Trump Tower last week. An apartment inside had been listed for rental through Airbnb.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: An apartment listed on the rental website until last week offered a prime location, luxurious appointments and a lot of security. It was inside Trump Tower.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: Prosecutor Pushes for Indictment of South Korean President in Samsung Scandal
item.media:description: The special prosecutor Park Young-soo, center, said on Monday that President Park Geun-hye and her confidante, Choi Soon-sil, conspired to collect $38 million in bribes from Samsung.
item.description: President Park Geun-hye, who cannot be charged while in office, is accused of conspiring with a confidante to take $38 million in bribes from the technology company.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: In Silicon Valley, Caltrain Upgrade Is Imperiled as Trump Withholds Funds
item.media:description: Construction was under way last month in Fresno, Calif., on the first leg of the high-speed rail line connecting San Francisco to Los Angeles. The high-speed rail project and Caltrain are administratively separate, but a 2013 agreement to share tracks as a cost-saving measure raised Republican ire.
item.description: The Trump administration, backed by California Republicans, is withholding a $647 million federal grant for the electrification project, which has immediate consequences for the system’s 65,000 daily commuters.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Data Firm Says ‘Secret Sauce’ Aided Trump; Many Scoff
item.media:description: Alexander Nix, chief executive of Cambridge Analytica, at the Concordia Summit for public-private business partnerships in New York in September. The firm claimed to have developed psychographic profiles that could predict the political leanings of every American adult.
item.description: The big-data company Cambridge Analytica says it has the ability to predict the political leanings of every American adult, but how well it works remains unproved.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and DANNY HAKIM

item.title: The Week Ahead: Houston Will Host Energy Conference, and February Jobs Figures Are Due
item.description: The CERAWeek gathering will draw the Canadian prime minister and other international speakers. Meanwhile, analysts are expecting a solid monthly gain in jobs.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Bits: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Uber, Oh Boy.
item.description: Snap debuted on the New York Stock Exchange and raised over $3 billion. And three new blows to Uber.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO and MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Trump Inherits a Secret Cyberwar Against North Korean Missiles
item.media:description: An image distributed by the North Korean government showing the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, visiting a missile test center in North Pyongan Province. Analysts say the pair of engines he is standing in front of could power an intercontinental ballistic missile.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.description: The United States has been trying to sabotage North Korea’s missile program. President Trump must decide what to do next.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 북한 미사일 방해 전략, 뻔한 곳에 숨겨져 있었다.
item.media:description: 미국 공군 준장으로 예편한 케네스 E. 토도로프(사진 가운데)는 지난 2015년 워싱턴에 있는 전략국제문제연구소(CSIS)에서 열린 세미나에 참석해 미사일에 대한 선제타격을 어떤 방식으로 재가할 것인지에 대한 질문을 제기했다.
item.description: 미국 정부 관계자들은 자세한 언급은 피하면서도 사이버 공격과 색다른 형태의 미사일 무력화 작전을 포함해 미국의 미사일 방어 체계를 다시 정의해야 한다고 공개적으로 말해 왔다.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Palm Springs Is Hot. The Old Guard Is Hot Under the Collar.
item.media:description: The midcentury home of J.R. Roberts, a city councilman in Palm Springs, Calif.
item.media:credit: Emily Berl for The New York Times
item.description: Long a sleepy city that drew Hollywood stars, this desert oasis is grappling with a surge in short-term home rentals.
item.dc:creator: KATHERINE ROSMAN

item.title: This Life: Whom Do You Tell When You’re Sick? Maybe Everyone You Know
item.description: People used to keep medical conditions private, but “a tweet-length piece of information can be the difference between life and death,” says a doctor.
item.dc:creator: BRUCE FEILER

item.title: Blockchain: A Better Way to Track Pork Chops, Bonds, Bad Peanut Butter?
item.media:description: Cargo containers are loaded on a Maersk ship at the Port of Mombasa in Kenya. IBM has heated competition in the race to monitor transactions.
item.media:credit: Andrew Renneisen for The New York Times
item.description: Walmart is testing real-world uses for the arcane technology behind the cryptocurrency Bitcoin, but significant challenges remain.
item.dc:creator: NATHANIEL POPPER and STEVE LOHR

item.title: Howard Schmidt, Cybersecurity Adviser to Two Presidents, Dies at 67
item.media:description: Howard A. Schmidt speaking at the Sixth International Information Security Conference in Seoul, South Korea, in 2012.
item.description: A computer crime expert, Mr. Schmidt was recruited by Presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama and drafted safeguards that were approved by Congress.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.category: National Strategy for Trusted Identities in Cyberspace

item.title: Uber Said to Consider Changes to Employee Stock Compensation
item.media:description: Uber headquarters in San Francisco. The company is said to be discussing how to make it easier for employees who leave to take their stock with them.
item.description: Uber is considering ways to make its stock compensation policies more friendly to its workers, said people with knowledge of a meeting where the issue was discussed.
item.dc:creator: KATIE BENNER and MIKE ISAAC

item.title: The Workologist: Getting Real About the Fantasy of a Fresh Start
item.description: An exhausted couple consider chucking their high-paying jobs in New York and moving to a small town upstate.
item.dc:creator: ROB WALKER

item.title: How Uber Deceives the Authorities Worldwide
item.media:description: Uber’s Greyball tool was developed to weed out riders thought to be using its service improperly.
item.description: A program uses data Uber collected to evade law enforcement in cities that resist the ride-hailing service, some current and former Uber employees said.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Tech Tip: How to Use a Hearing Aid with Your Smartphone
item.description: The iPhone and other mobile phones include tools and settings to help people with hearing loss.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: Snap’s I.P.O. Went Well. Now What?
item.media:description: Snap, the maker of Snapchat, had a strong trading debut on Thursday.
item.description: As the maker of the ephemeral messaging app Snapchat started trading on the New York Stock Exchange, shares soared to 44 percent over their offering price.
item.dc:creator: PUI-WING TAM

item.title: Critic's Notebook: How to Escape Your Political Bubble for a Clearer View
item.media:description: Venturing outside the bias bubble.
item.description: Want to see how the other half live-tweets? The technology that insulated you will now free you.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA HESS
